subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit test class reloading patch
msgSnippet: Hi Erich, You may also want to take a look at how SuiteRunner loads classes. Each recipe includes a runpath, from which it loads the classes of the test.
messageBody:
Hi Erich,

You may also want to take a look at how SuiteRunner loads classes. Each
recipe includes a "runpath," from which it loads the classes of the
test. Here's a paragraph from the tutorial:

A runpath is the list of filenames, directory paths, and/or URLs that
Artima SuiteRunner uses to load classes for the running test. If
runpath is specified, Artima SuiteRunner creates a
java.net.URLClassLoader to load classes available on the runpath. The
graphical user interface can optionally reload the test classes for
each run by creating a new URLClassLoader for each run. If the
executable JAR file is available on the Java classpath, then the
classes that comprise the test may also be made available on the
classpath and no runpath need be specified.

You can put whatever you want on the classpath and runpath. The stuff
on the runpath (test classes, app classes, junit.jar if you want to run
JUnit tests, etc...) can be reloaded before each test. I think that's
basically what you guys are talking about for JUnit, except that I used
URLClassLoader not a custom class loader. URLClassLoader works for
local files, but I also wanted to make it possible to load JAR files
across the network, to support testing of distributed systems with
mobile code, such as Jini systems.

http://www.artima.com/suiterunner/start.html

Bill

On Monday, July 21, 2003, at 04:38 PM, Erich Gamma wrote:

>

> Hi Scott,
>
> moving to a Java 2 ClassLoader is the right direction.
>
> If I understand it properly then only the test cases are
> on the junit.test.path. This means only test cases
> can be reloaded, but not application classes.
> If this is correct then I don't see how the solution handles
> the case where a fix to a test requires a change in
> an application class. Since the application class
> isn't reloaded the test runner needs to be restarted.
>

> Hi,
>
> I'd like to propose a fix for JUnit test class reloading. The
> proposed fix
> is a Java 2 custom ClassLoader that loads test classes from its own
> classpath and always delegates to the system/parent ClassLoader first
> without relying on anything like excluded.properties to filter system
> and
> non-system classes.
>
> note: this is how Servlets, JSPs, EJBs, etc. are reloaded dynamically
> on
> change by J2EE containers that support dynamic reloads -- the Servlet,
> JSPs,
> EJBs, etc. are not on the system classpath, so the system classloader
> can
> always be delegated to and will not find the classes and this leave it
> to
> the custom loader(s) to load them. All defined in the Java 2
> ClassLoader
> delegation contract.
>
> The proposed means of configuring the custom loader's classpath is to
> use a
> Java system property named "junit.test.path". This can be set as a
> command
> line argument, or could be read from a properties file.
>
> I have implemented this proposal in a small patch that can be
> downloaded
> here:
> http://users.rcn.com/scottstirling/junit-patch.jar.
>
> A regression test (XmlTest.java) and series of steps for reproducing
> the
> original TestCaseClassLoader bug and running the test with the patch
> are
> here:
> http://users.rcn.com/scottstirling/2003/07/19.html#a61
>
> Thank you,
> Scott Stirling
> Framingham, MA
